forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content:
Hi,  

I've been using ventoy for a while now and I love it.  
But there's a problem I have.  

I made an Multiboot-USB Stick. With ventoy so easy.  
But if I edit an ISO the error: "No bootfile found for UEFI! Maybe the image does not support X64 UEFI!" occured.  

In this case it's Acronis 2019.  
Inside iso is a file for Mac: AcronisTrueImage2019-17000.dmg  
I delete this one to safe space. Now I boot and get the error.  

Kaspersky rescue disc the same.  

But I did the same thing with Acronis 2017 ago... this worked fine.  

I use PowerISO or UltraIso to edit the isos.  

Can someone help me with this?  

Best regards ![biggrin.png](https://forums.ventoy.net/images/smilies/biggrin.png "Big Grin")

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: Are you testing booting on a real system?

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content:
Hi ![:D](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/biggrin.png)

On a real system.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: Does the modified ISO UEFI-boot from an Easy2Boot v2 USB drive?

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content: Can't test because I have no Easy2Boot USb drive.

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content:
So I've tested with Easy2Boot v2... same problem.  
"No bootfile found for UEFI"

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: OK - so if you extract the files from each ISO and compare the contents, what differences do you see?

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content: Content is the same. Only folder doc and the file AcronisTrueImage2019-17000.dmg are deleted. I had a screenshot but no idea how to attaching it ![:confused1:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/confused1.gif)

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content:
I made a new GPT ventoy stick with [Ventoy-1.0.18_Modified_EN](http://reboot.pro/topic/22328-ventoy-boot-grubfm-modified/ "") and Support for SecureBoot.

Now I get this error message:

ASSERT_EFI_ERROR (Status = Invalid Parameter)

ASSERT \[Ventoy\] /home/share/Ventoy/EDKII/edk2-edk2-stable201911/MdePkg/Library/UefiMemoryAllocationLib/MemoryAllocationLib.c(813): !EFI_ERROR (Status)

No bootfile found for UEFI!

Maybe the image does not support X64 UEFI!

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Are you sure the unmodified ISO boots OK?

I have downloaded AcronisTrueImage2019_14110.iso and it also gives a UEFI boot error in E2B UEFI64 agFM grub2 (unmodified).

It does not contain any dmg file. I think you can get ISOs for PC or for MAC - maybe yours is the MAC one?

AcronisTrueImage2019_14110.iso UEFI64 boots OK if I use the agFM .isomem boot option however.

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content:
Yes, it boots ok.

No, Its not the MAC one.

Only the modified doesn't boot uefi.

[Screenshot merged ISOs](https://ibb.co/Zh6DHnG "External link")

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: Check file contents using 7zip - so you can see \[BOOT\] files.

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content:
The files in \[BOOT\] folder are the same in both ISOs:

1. 1-Boot-NoEmul.img size: 2048  
2. 2-Boot-NoEmul.img size: 0

Hmm, can it be some kind of signature?

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: How can it UEFI-boot if there are no .EFI boot files???

forumNotes.author: alacran
nierewa
forumNotes.content:
> UEFI boot files should be located into efi folder It sems that there are more then one ISO-Versions outside. As I wrote in Post 1 the Acronis 2017 ISO has the same content like your 2016 ISO. The Acronis 2019 ISO unmodified boots UEFI.
> AcronisTrueImage2019_14110.iso UEFI64 boots OK if I use the agFM .isomem boot option however. As I wrote I use the modified ventoy Version. If I boot .isomem nothing happens. Can you tell me how you did this?

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
My ISO contains a EFI folder. I don't see how your ISO can UEFI boot as it does not have EFI files - are you SURE it UEFI boots when unmodified?

To test:

I just made an E2B v2.04 USB drive using Windows 10

Added the ISO to \\_ISO\\BACKUP folder

UEFI64 booted

and chose the .isomem option.  

#### Attached Thumbnails {#attach_wrap}

* [![acroniscontents.JPG](http://reboot.pro/uploads/monthly_08_2020/post-17818-0-77348500-1597392773_thumb.jpg)](http://reboot.pro/uploads/monthly_08_2020/post-17818-0-77348500-1597392773.jpg "acroniscontents.JPG - Size: 139.14KB"){#ipb-attach-url-17312-0-93062800-1676066383}

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> I use PowerISO or UltraIso to edit the isos.  

Then don't and instead of editing a .iso (that by definition cannot be edited) re-create one.

Making a .iso that dual boots BIOS and UEFI is "tough" and it is very likely - not to say probable - that the original .iso has \*some\* settings\[1\] that "generic automagic" tools like PowerIso or UltraIso simply miss, or at least that was the case before:  
[https://msfn.org/boa...comment=1080917](https://msfn.org/board/topic/172122-got-tips-on-how-to-make-a-bootable-cd-from-bootable-usb/?do=findComment&comment=1080917 "External link")

Compare with:  
<http://reboot.pro/topic/21664-makeiso/>

[http://reboot.pro/to...-under-windows/](http://reboot.pro/topic/20247-biosefi-hybrid-iso-creation-under-windows/ "")

Basically you need to understand how (EXACTLY) the original .iso is made and then find a way to recreate it with mkisofs or oscdimg, start here:  
[https://msfn.org/boa...-torito-images/](https://msfn.org/board/topic/172655-strange-or-odd-multi-or-single-boot-cddvd-el-torito-images/ "External link")

![:duff:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/duff.gif)

Wonko

\[1\] possibly unrelated, but Acronis has historically made "strange" .iso's:  
[http://reboot.pro/to...-grub2-at-uefi/](http://reboot.pro/topic/20004-boot-a-acronis-true-image-2014-iso-image-with-grub2-at-uefi/ "")

[https://msfn.org/boa...oot-on-uefi-pc/](https://msfn.org/board/topic/172610-acronis-iso-boot-on-uefi-pc/ "External link")

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
> 2. 2-Boot-NoEmul.img size: 0

.

Compare this at ImDisk or ISOBuster.

.  
This is the EFI boot image, It's a approximate 400 MB floppy image.

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content:
> Compare this at ImDisk or ISOBuster.

Comparing with IsoBuster shows the difference

[![isobuster.jpg](https://reboot.pro/uploads/monthly_08_2020/post-21205-0-04329700-1597605526_thumb.jpg)](https://reboot.pro/uploads/monthly_08_2020/post-21205-0-04329700-1597605526.jpg "isobuster.jpg - Size: 81.52KB"){#ipb-attach-url-17324-0-00818700-1675925656}

There only three entrys in Spur 1 in the modified ISO and the BiitImage.img with 0kib

Strange

forumNotes.author: nierewa
Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Strange

Please read as "normal for Acronis", as seen in the given threads.

What very likely happens is that the size of the boot image is mis-reported, not entirely unlike what happened here:  
[http://reboot.pro/to...ting-iso-files/](http://reboot.pro/topic/12406-editing-iso-files/ "")

with a "more normal" isolinux .iso.

![:duff:](https://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/duff.gif)

Wonko

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
> Comparing with IsoBuster shows the difference

The original ISO contains two \~ 400 MB boot images.

Guessed: one PC and another Mac one. Then one image should be mountable at ImDisk.

The boot images are missing at the edited ISO, UEFI boot fails.

forumNotes.author: nierewa
forumNotes.content:
Ok, I give up.  
So I use the original Image instead.

Thanks all for your help ![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif)

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
I wonder the file size: why a 1.6 GB ISO image?  
Dosn't Acronis offer a about 700 MB CD image anymore?
